item.title: Qualifying for Legal Residency in Mexico
item.description: So you want to become a resident of Mexico but don’t know where to start? Well, it isn’t as easy as just moving to Mexico and you are a resident. You have to follow specific steps to become one. If you are thinking of just getting a FMM (AKA Tourist Visa) and live in Mexico on it, those days are rapidly coming to an end. INM (Mexican Immigration) has now networked their systems so that they can see who is trying to game the system and live in Mexico without follow the legal process.

item.title: It is time to pay annual bonuses
item.description:
It is that time of the year again where workers are given their yearly bonuses. This is NOT an optional thing either. Mexico’s previous President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador (AMLO) completely redid the Mexico Ley de Trabajo and this is what it says now:

Article 87.- Workers will have the right to an annual bonus that must be paid before the twentieth of December, equivalent to at least fifteen days of salary. Those who have not completed the year of service, regardless of whether they are working or not on the date of settlement of the bonus, will have the right to be paid the proportional part of it, according to the time they have worked, whatever this may be.

item.title: What is a Digital Nomad VPN?
item.description:
Digital Nomad VPN Guide

Introduction

Let’s start this off with a few explanations so you can better understand some basic concepts.

First, think of the Internet as a giant map. There are addresses where you can access specific things, and only those addresses. To reach them, you type in something like www.IDontWantToBeHere.com (I don‚Äôt think that site actually exists) and hit enter in your web browser. Most people don‚Äôt know how that actually works. Your Internet provider takes that website‚Äôs URL and looks it up in a ‚Äúphone book‚Äù until it finds a ‚Äúphone number‚Äù used to dial that location. When you enter that address, the phone book shows the address 127.0.0.1 and dials that number. It‚Äôs that simple.

item.title: The Amazing SR-71
item.description:
The Blackbird

Many people don‚Äôt realize there were actually two aircraft nicknamed the Blackbird. The first was the A‚Äë12, built by the CIA as a single‚Äëseat reconnaissance aircraft. It was designated ‚ÄúA‚Äë12‚Äù because it was the twelfth design in the Archangel series ‚Äî ‚ÄúArchangel‚Äù being the program‚Äôs code name.

Lockheed and Convair competed to build a replacement for the U‚Äë2, which had become vulnerable to Soviet radar and missiles. The CIA initially favored Convair‚Äôs Kingfish design, but Lockheed‚Äôs A‚Äë12 offered better specifications at lower cost. Track record mattered too: Convair‚Äôs B‚Äë58 Hustler had been plagued by delays and overruns, while Lockheed had delivered the U‚Äë2 on time and under budget.

item.title: SR-71 Specifications
item.description:
General Characteristics

Dimensions and Capacities

Specification Value
Crew 2
Length 107 ft 5 in (32.74 m)
Wingspan 55 ft 7 in (16.94 m)
Height 18 ft 6 in (5.64 m)
Wheel track 16 ft 8 in (5.00 m)
Wheelbase 37 ft 10 in (12.00 m)
Aspect ratio 1.7
Wing area 1,800 sq ft (170 sq m)
Empty weight 67,500 lbs (30,617 kg)
Gross weight 152,000 lbs (68,946 kg)
Max takeoff weight 172,000 lbs (78,018 kg)
Fuel capacity 12,219 US gal (46,255 L)
Powerplant 2 √ó Pratt & Whitney J58

Context

  • The SR‚Äë71‚Äôs crew of two (pilot and reconnaissance systems officer) was essential: one flew the aircraft, the other managed sensors and navigation at extreme speeds.
  • Its length of 107 feet made it longer than a Boeing 737, yet its wingspan of only 55 feet gave it a sleek, dart‚Äëlike profile optimized for supersonic flight.
  • The aspect ratio of 1.7 shows how stubby the wings were ‚Äî designed for speed, not maneuverability.
  • The fuel capacity of over 12,000 gallons was necessary because the J58 engines consumed fuel at astonishing rates. Even then, the SR‚Äë71 often required multiple aerial refuelings during missions.
  • The Pratt & Whitney J58 engines were unique: they operated as turbojets at lower speeds but transitioned to a hybrid turbojet/ramjet mode above Mach 2.5, allowing sustained Mach 3+ flight.

Performance

Specification Value
Maximum speed 1,910 kn (2,200 mph)
Maximum Mach Mach 3.3+
Ferry range 2,824 nmi (3,250 mi)
Service ceiling 85,000 ft
Rate of climb 11,820 ft/min
Wing loading 84 lbs/sq ft

Context

  • The SR‚Äë71‚Äôs maximum speed of 2,200 mph meant it could outrun threats rather than dodge them. Pilots often joked that ‚Äúspeed was life.‚Äù
  • Its Mach 3.3+ capability wasn‚Äôt just a headline number ‚Äî the aircraft could cruise at those speeds for hours, something no other operational jet has matched.
  • The service ceiling of 85,000 feet placed it well above most surface‚Äëto‚Äëair missile envelopes and fighter interceptors. Pilots reported seeing the curvature of the Earth and the deep black of space.
  • A rate of climb of nearly 12,000 ft/min allowed the SR‚Äë71 to reach operational altitude quickly, minimizing exposure during takeoff and ascent.
  • The wing loading of 84 lbs/sq ft reflected its design trade‚Äëoff: small wings for speed meant high wing loading, making the aircraft less agile but perfectly suited for straight‚Äëline reconnaissance runs.

Notes

  • All dimensions are approximate.
  • Weights reflect a typical operational configuration.
  • Speeds represent maximum achievable under optimal conditions.

Context

  • The SR‚Äë71‚Äôs numbers don‚Äôt tell the whole story. Its titanium skin expanded several inches during flight due to heat, which is why the aircraft leaked fuel on the ground ‚Äî the seals only tightened at high speeds.
  • The aircraft‚Äôs performance envelope was so extreme that even routine missions required careful planning of refueling points, weather conditions, and threat assessments.
  • Despite its complexity, the SR‚Äë71 flew for over 30 years without ever being shot down, cementing its reputation as one of the greatest engineering achievements in aviation history.

item.title: The Blackbird Family Comparison
item.description:
‚úàÔ∏è Blackbird Family Comparison: A-12, YF-12, and SR-71

The Blackbird family represents one of the most remarkable lineages in aviation history. Born from Lockheed‚Äôs Skunk Works during the height of the Cold War, these aircraft pushed the limits of speed, altitude, and stealth. The A‚Äë12, YF‚Äë12, and SR‚Äë71 were closely related in design but served very different missions: clandestine CIA reconnaissance, high‚Äëspeed interception, and long‚Äërange USAF strategic reconnaissance. Together, they showcase how a single airframe concept evolved into multiple specialized roles ‚Äî each breaking records and shaping aerospace engineering for decades to come.

item.title: Network Troubleshooting Scripts
item.description: I recently had problems with my Digital Nomad VPN setup. I went to the GL.iNet Discord and asked for help but they wanted results from various tests to be able to help me. I provided those responses but felt there had to be a better way. I saw these types of questions asked all the time in the tech support sub of GL.iNet’s Discourd. I found that there were very few options out there that allowed you to find a single, simple source with logs to troubleshoot a VPN network and decided to create my own. With the assistance of “Wicked Yoda”, I created these and shared them. Wicked has taken on the torch to building these troubleshooting tools. You can find them here: https://github.com/wickedyoda/Network-Diag-Utilities

item.title: The Misadventures in Moving - Day 3
item.description: The next morning, I get up, get on my laptop and contact a friend from boarding school that lives in Mexico City. Pedro gives me some tips for the rest of my trip into Mexico - always tip people 10 pesos or so if they fill your gas tank (Mexico is a “full service” country where you cannot fill your own gas tank!), and gives us the name of the place to go to exchange our US dollars for pesos. Dipshit Farmers had gone to Mexico before but they took US dollars and we thought it was that way still. NOPE! Mexico implemented new rules that was intended to stop money-laundering. Anyhow, Pedro tells us to go to a “casa de cambio” to get that done. We find one on the map and program it into my wife’s GPS.

item.title: The Misadventures in Moving - Day 2
item.description:
We wake up the next morning and it is late - 11 AM or so. We wanted to sleep and be on the road by 9am but that just didn’t happen. I sneak the cats back into the van and we start on the move once more.

As we are driving away, we noticed that the air conditioneer wasn’t blowing cold. I had just put freon in yesterday before we left Albuquerque!!!! I decide to go get more freon and put it in in the parking lot by the Motel 6. When I go to put it in, I noticed my error. I forgot to put the cap on the line yesterday so all the freon came out!!! I can be an idiot at times!

item.title: The Misadventures in Moving - Day 1
item.description:
Moving to Mexico was a rushed endeavor for us. We were moving down to Mexico in a used minivan that we bought just for the move. You cannot rent a U-Haul to move across international borders. The van we bought has cheap and the plan was to get to Mexico and then just get rid of it. That turns out not to be something you can do.

To say we were not properly prepared for this move is an understatement of the century. We were basing things on what we knew about living in the United States, and from our couple of trips to Puerto Penasco, Mexico AKA Rocky Point, or, as my girlfriend at the time kept calling Pina Colada because she was drunk. Needless to say, things changed!

item.title: How I became a digital nomad?
item.description: I was on my way to graduate school in Germany back in 2015. I got as far as Amsterdam when I ended up being hospitalized for 15 days. 7 days in was when graduate school started. The Germans wouldn’t let me have a late start so I had to return to the US. We had already sold our house by then so I needed to move somewhere fast. My requirements were that the place was inexpensive, had great internet service, was near a major international airport, and that “snow” was a foreign language and the only ice you got was in your drink.

item.title: How and why I moved to Mexico?
item.description:
I got in my van and drove there! ;)

Okay, I will be serious. I really didn’t have a choice but to move. In my case, I had just come home from a failed attempt to start school in Germany. We were in a bad situation - we had sold our house already, needed to move to somewhere for 6 months and live on a student’s budget. We needed to have good Internet, be near a major international airport, and inexpensive.
